Title: Wide Streets Commission Jury Book Volume 08 Item 18
Transcription:
1
Royal Exchange
Monday 26th January 1801

Commissioner Present  Captain  Burgh
Jury sworn 12th. Jany inst. for Valuation of Premises in Dame Street and Abbey Street.

The Jury are called
Geo: Dowdall absent
A Note is sent by Mr. Dowdall mentioning that Business of a most particular nature (which he would explain if necessary on the next day of Meeting) prevents him from attending this day

Adjourned to Monday the second of February next Notice thereof to be inserted in the usual papers

Title: Wide Streets Commission Jury Book Volume 08 Item 19
Transcription:
Royal Exchange
Thursday 29th January 1801

Commissioner Present Jeremiah D'Olier Esq.
Jury Sworn 28th August last _

Jury called. they appear

Cut Purse Row
Mr. Thomas Sharkey attends and claims an interest in the Premises in Cut Purse Row No 7 and 8 under a Deed of annuity of twenty pounds Granted him by the Representatives of Barbara Worrale in Consideration of the sum therein mentioned.

Reps. of Charles White
Mr. Sherrard Attends. pursuant to the Order of the 22nd. instant and produces the Minute Books of the Commissioners relative to their Agreement with Charles White for his Ground and premises in Cut Purse Row.

Commissioners Law Agent reads the following
Note stated in the Comrs. Minutes of the 19th. of June 1794. Book No 12.

"Charles Whites best respects to Mr. Sherrard, wishes
"to inform you before I begin that I do intend 
"immediately to rebuild Cut Purse Row and thought
"proper to let you know it. but if the Commissioners 
intend a fresh Valuation I would defer it for some longer
TranscriptionNoTags:

Thursday 29th January 1801

Commissioner Present Jeremiah D'Olier Esq.

Jury called. they appear

Cut Purse Row
Mr. Thomas Sharkey attends and claims an interest in the Premises in Cut Purse Row No 7 and 8 under a Deed of annuity of twenty pounds Granted him by the Representatives of Barbara Worrale in Consideration of the sum therein mentioned.

Reps. of Charles White
Mr. Sherrard Attends. pursuant to the Order of the 22nd. instant and produces the Minute Books of the Commissioners relative to their Agreement with Charles White for his Ground and premises in Cut Purse Row.

Commissioners Law Agent reads the following
Note stated in the Comrs. Minutes of the 19th. of June 1794. Book No 12.

"Charles Whites best respects to Mr. Sherrard, wishes
"to inform you before I begin that I do intend 
"immediately to rebuild Cut Purse Row and thought
"proper to let you know it. but if the Commissioners 
intend a fresh Valuation I would defer it for some longer

37 Pill lane 6th. June 1794

"Ordered that Mr. White be requested to state to 
"the Board. what compensation he will require to
"erect the part of his new intended  Buildings in
"Cutpurse Row in a range with the Buildings now
"standing east thereof North side of Corn Market

Read Minutes of the 8th. August 1794 Book 12

"Sir
"I received your Letter of the 16 June last I 
"would have answered  much sooner, but for want 
"of a compleat Map of the Ground

"You will be pleased to acquaint the 
"Commissioners of Wide Streets that the Compensation
"I will require for setting back my Buildings in
"Cutpurse row in a line or Range with the Houses
"I lately erected North side of Corn Market and
"immedately adjoining to said intended Houses on
"the east side is £2000 I am at present in treaty
"for selling apart or the whole of said Ground for
"Building and intreat a speedy answer as I have
"been a Considerable looser by having been so long
"prevented from selling it.     
"I am etc etc 
Charles White
"1st. August 1794

Mr. William Lewis Walker. Agent for the Represents. of Charles White alleges that the Commissioners considered the front Ground to Cutpurse Row worth the sum of two thousand pounds and that his reason for requiring the Minute Books of the Commissioners to be produced was, to show to the Jury the Value of the Ground in the year 1794.

House in the possession of Michael Doyle reserving liberty of passage through the entry situate on the South side of said House for John Silk and his tenants Servants and followers.  To Hold from the said first day of December then inst. for the term of sixty one years at the yearly rent of one pepper corn for the last year thereof and the yearly rent of eight pounds for the first sixty years, with a covenant that the said Thomas Mansfield should keep the said House insured against fire every year to the amount of three hundred pounds, or in default thereof to pay an additional rent of twenty pounds every year he should neglect to insure same.

That said Thomas Mansfield for many years carried on the Business of a leather cutter in part of a shop in new Row within two doors of his present shop during which time his trade and property increased every year - being opposite to the Market House and in the centre of the four Avenues to the city where such Goods are always sold but on finding from the encrease of his business that his shop was too small and having no lease thereof he on the first day of December 1787 obtained a Lease of his present House being next but one to his former situation for 61 years and paid £80 as afine but though same was to remain for the last years rent

That he expended a considerable sum in repairs and in enlarging said shop which from its situation had been divided into two, and his Business was so increased on account of his central situation and establishment in that part  of the Neighbourhood that he for the last ten years sold as much Goods as any other man in his line and can prove that during the las year he purchased Leather and sold same in his shop to the amount of £10,000 whereby his profits for said year were £700 that is £400 .. by his wholesale & £300 by his retail trade which if required he can prove by  Danners  and his own account Books all which advantages he must now relinquish for the public convenience after he has surmounted all other difficulties to get into estimation and credit.

That he being now obliged to quit his situation, his future trade will most materially be injured and hurt as country Buyers who pay ready money for everey Article always apply to the shop they last purchased at or as near to it and their market way home as they can, and though a stranger to the seller would not give the preferrence to an acquantance by crossing the street to his shop or searching for it tho' but

That as these are indisputable facts some idea may be formed therefrom of the value of this house to Mr. Mansfield for the remaining term of his lease, and as nothing but the present compulsion could induce him during his life to part with his shop he has often refused to set one third of it to a sadler for £40 a year altho he could thereby with the rents he receives for his cellar and a street bulk four feet square live almost rent free, and if he was inclined to let the remainder of said house and shop and retire from business he could receive upwards of £57 a year profit rent thereout as follows

Title: Wide Streets Commission Jury Book Volume 08 Item 26
Transcription:
9
Royal Exchange
Thursday 19 January 1801

That the foregoing valuation has been made of the whole of the premises on the supposition that the entire will be wanting for opening Cut-purse Row but as it is presumed that only a part will be necessary for that purpose a proportion only of the foregoing valuation can be looked for ∼

That in the year 1790 his interest in said premises was valued by a Jury (who were appointed for that purpose) to so small a sum as £500 but that since that time his retail and wholesale trade has increased nearly double from his continuation ever since in said shop, & that his establishment and connextions have become very extensive & submits that though his term therein has decreased his  interest  must be of much more considerable value than it was at that period by his great establishment for the last 10 years∼

That under the peculiar circmstances of his case he submits that his claim is reasonable and fair & hopes his fellow citizens will consider his case as their own, he relies on their justice & entreats their protection to save him and his family from ruin, who until now had the fairest prospect of making a very ample and independant property ∼
Thos. Mansfield

Evidence John Smyth/sworn  Says he lived for 7 years next door to Thos. Mansfield in New Row & thinks his situation one of the best in the city & knows that

That the foregoing valuation has been made of the whole of the premises on the supposition that the entire will be wanting for opening Cut-purse Row but as it is presumed that only a part will be necessary for that purpose a proportion only of the foregoing valuation can be looked for ∼

That in the year 1790 his interest in said premises was valued by a Jury (who were appointed for that purpose) to so small a sum as £500 but that since that time his retail and wholesale trade has increased nearly double from his continuation ever since in said shop, & that his establishment and connextions have become very extensive & submits that though his term therein has decreased his  interest  must be of much more considerable value than it was at that period by his great establishment for the last 10 years∼

That under the peculiar circmstances of his case he submits that his claim is reasonable and fair & hopes his fellow citizens will consider his case as their own, he relies on their justice & entreats their protection to save him and his family from ruin, who until now had the fairest prospect of making a very ample and independant property ∼

known Porter House called the Turkey Cock in New Row and from thence resided therein and expended considerable sums in improvements thereon and on the first day of December 1787 he paid a fine of twenty guineas and obtained a lease thereof from the late Timothy Mahon for 61 years at £20- per year

That such house being the best standing in that neighbourhood and resorted to for several years by the most respectable neighbours and gentlemen from all parts of the City the business was encreasing till the Commissioners for Wide Streets caused a Jury to value it about January 1790 and from thence the customers went elsewhere and the business declined so that petitioners husband became embarrassed which occasioned his death leaving petr. with five infant children reduced from affluence to want the common necessaries of life ∼

Commissioner present
Jury sworn 12th. January last for valuation of Dame St. Fownses Street &

Jury are called
Mr Murphy    }
Mr Guinness }  absent

They appear

Mr. George  McGusty  comes forward on the part of the representatives of Michael Butler and states to the Jury that Mr. Daly who is the agent for the reps. of John Cope, having alleged on a prior day before the Jury, that there was a bill filed in the Court of Chancery, by which the lease under Hugh Russell as representative of John Cope, and made to the said Michael Butler had been stated to have been fraudulently obtained & Mr. McGusty produced attested copys of the several proceedings in the cause by which it appeared that the Court of Chancery confirmed said leases and dismissed said bill with costs

The Jury enter into the following resolutions

Resolved That this Jury shall not be again summoned untill Mr. Lyster shall have the positive promise of a Commissioner that he will attend them as they have had four adjournments from the non attendance of Comrs.

Randal McAllister formerly of the City of Dublin Booksellers were possessed of the house and concerns No 59 Dame Street by lease bearing date the 22nd. day of April 1789 and made to them by Hester Doyle and Anne Harpur for the term of 800 years in consideration of £200 fine and carried on business very extensively therein until the year 1791 at which period they separated when said Arthur Gruber in order to secure the business to himself gave said Randall McAllister the sum of £500 sterling besides a rent - charge of £20 on said house

That on the 22nd. day of Decr. 1793 said George Follingsby by  inesne  assignmt. became possessed of said house and concerns, and by a considerable expence in making alterations and advertizing has established himself in the bookselling and stationary business the profits whereof, with saving by lodging as herein after mentioned are upwards of £700 sterling a year

That said house has been built within fifty years last past and is at present in excellent repair and condition ∼ besides the taxes being unusually low in comparison

To the Right Honble and Honble the Commissioners for the making wide and convenient streets and the Jury for valuing the houses between Fowens.s Street and Crow Street in the City of Dublin

The Memorial of Catherine Harper of the City of Dublin spinster

Sheweth
That Memorialist is entitled to a profit rent of fifty four pounds a year payable out of the dwelling house situate on the north side of Dame Street No. 59 wherein George Folingsby bookseller now lives for a term of nine hundred and ninety nine years which commenced the twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and eighty three subject to a rent of forty six pounds twelve shillings and nine pence yearly under a lease executed to the Memorialists late mother of Catherine Harper by Joseph Maddock of the City of Dublin hatter

That notice by publick advertizmt. hath been given that the interests of the several persons entitled to said house will be valued by

Title: Wide Streets Commission Jury Book Volume 08 Item 75
Transcription:
58
Royal Exchange
Monday 23rd. March 1801

valued by a Jury under your honors authority pursuant to the statutes in that behalf -

That Memorialist is a single woman and that the profit rent so payable to her out of said house is the sole fund for her subsistance that such provision is exceedingly well  seemed  to her as the tenant has considble interest therein

That Memorialist being called upon to sell her interest in said house for the public convenience which she hath on her part no necessity or inclination to do she therefore humbly hopes that the gentlemen of the Jury in the valuation of her interest will award her the sum of one thousand one hundred and thirty four pounds as a compensation for her very valuable interest in a nine hundred years lease

That Memorialist is ready to prove her title to your honors and the Jury impannelled

May it therefore please your honors to take Memorialists case into considn. and to act therein as in your wisdom and justice shall seem meet

59
Royal Exchange
Monday 23rd March 1801

Mrs Maddock appears as represe. of John Maddock and claims a profit rent of twenty eight pounds two shillings and nine pence arising out of said house No. 59 Dame Street

Memorial stated
That John Maddock late of the City of Dublin being possessed of the residue of a term of nine hundred and ninety seven years of an house on the north side of Dame Street No. 59 from the twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and thirty at the yearly rent of eighteen pounds ten shillings by indenture bearing date the first of April one thousand seven hundred and eighty three demised the premises for nine hundred years from the twenty fifth March last past to Mrs. Catherine Harper at the yearly rent of forty six pounds twelve shillings and nine pence sterling.

He afterwards on the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and ninety four duly made and published his last will and testement and thereby devised said premes to his daughter Anne and appointed his wife sole

Royal Exchange
Monday 23rd March 1801

twenty ninth day of September then next for ninety nine years at the yearly rent of sixteen pounds sterling ∼

1777 21 August
By deed of conveyance of this date the above lease became vested in Robert Moore late of the City of Dublin glazier deceased who entered and enjoyed the premises until the time of his death -

1788 6 March
By deed of mortgage of this date the said Robert Moore in consideration of one hundred and ten pounds to him lent by Robert Marchbank printer assigned to him the said house and premises subject to redemption

1788 25 October
The said Robert Marchbank died but before his death made and published his last will of this date by which he devised the said house and premises to his widow Mary Dunne otherwise Moore and afterwards to his daughter Mary the wife of Thomas Craig of Dublin tea dealer and appointed his said wife Mary Moore and his said daughter Mary Craig executors and the said Mary Moore alone proved the will and obtined administration thereof ∼
1791

Title: Wide Streets Commission Jury Book Volume 08 Item 79
Transcription:
62
Royal Exchange
Monday 23 March 1801

1791 26th. May
By deed of assignment of mortgage of this date the said Robert Marchbank in onsideration of the principal and interest due to him and the said Mary Moore Thomas Craig and Mary his wife in consideration of a further sum let to them by Mary Palmer of Dublin widow both sums making one hundred and fifty pounts granted in mortgage unto the said Mary Palmer the said house and premises subject to redemption

Mrs. Moore having informed Mrs. Palmer that a former Jury valued the foregoing house to the sum of five hundred pounds and upwards and Mrs. Moore under the idea of receiving the value of the concerns prevailed on Mrs. Palmer to wait until she should receive the value thereof out of which she should be paid her principal and interest and cost by which means an arrear of interest accrued due to her

Mrs. Palmer finding she neither received her principal or her interest threatened to foreclose her mortgage of the twenty sixth of May one thousand seven hundred and ninety one  Mrs. Moore thereupon applied to Mr. Patrick Kearney of this City who agreed to lend and advance the money due thereon
1800

of Memorialists a certain lot of ground situate on the north side of Dame Street and corner of Crow Street for a term of nine hundred and ninety seven years at the yearly rent of twenty four pounds ten shillings on which ground two dwelling houses have been erected to wit one in Dame Street set by lease to the late Mr. Lord for 99 years from March 1778 at the yearly rent of £60 which said house is now in the tenancy and occupation of Thomas Dixon hosier and the other house which is built on the rere of said lott of ground in Crow Street was let by lease to the late John Adair for 99 years from September 1731 at the yearly rent of £16 leaving a clear profit rent of fifty one pounds ten shillings as at foot which profit rent Memorialist humbly conceived to be worth 20 years purchase in as much as there is upwards of nine hundred and ninety years of said term unexpired and the said profit rent is not only equally well secured as ground rent but has an expectancy of a considerable rise on the expiration of the tenants leases

Your Memorialist therefore prays you will take his case into consideration and grant twenty years
